content: The Employee Free Choice Act of 2016 may be cited as the "Employee Free Choice Act". It includes provisions for streamlining union certification. The Employee Free Choice Act of 2016, also known as the "Employee Free Choice Act," amends Section 9(c) of the National Labor Relations Act. It allows for streamlined union certification by investigating petitions filed by employees or labor organizations seeking representation for collective bargaining purposes. If a majority of employees in a suitable bargaining unit have signed valid authorizations for a specific representative, the Board will not certify any other representative for that unit. The Employee Free Choice Act amends Section 9(c) of the National Labor Relations Act to streamline union certification by investigating petitions for representation. If a majority of employees in a unit have signed valid authorizations for a representative, the Board will certify that representative. The Board will develop guidelines and procedures for designation of a bargaining representative by employees. The Employee Free Choice Act amends Section 9(c) of the National Labor Relations Act to streamline union certification procedures. Amendments include changes to Section 8(b) regarding unfair labor practices. SEC. 3. FACILITATING INITIAL COLLECTIVE BARGAINING AGREEMENTS. Section 8 of the National Labor Relations Act is amended to include provisions for initial collective bargaining agreements following certification or recognition. Parties must meet within 10 days of a request for bargaining and make reasonable efforts to reach an agreement within 90 days. The National Labor Relations Act is amended to include provisions for initial collective bargaining agreements. If parties fail to reach an agreement, mediation can be requested, and if unsuccessful, the dispute will be referred to an arbitration board. The National Labor Relations Act is amended to include provisions for initial collective bargaining agreements. Disputes that cannot be resolved through mediation will be referred to an arbitration board, whose decision will be binding for 2 years unless both parties agree otherwise in writing. SEC. 4. STRENGTHENING ENFORCEMENT. Injunctions Against Unfair Labor Practices During Organizing Drives are addressed in the amendment to Section 10(l) of the National Labor Relations Act. This amendment specifies actions that constitute unfair labor practices by employers. The amendment to Section 10(l) of the National Labor Relations Act addresses unfair labor practices by employers during organizing drives. It prioritizes the investigation of charges related to such practices over other cases. The amendment to Section 10(l) of the National Labor Relations Act prioritizes investigating unfair labor practices by employers during organizing drives, giving them precedence over other cases. Additionally, Section 10(c) is amended to address remedies for violations, including backpay for discrimination against employees seeking representation by a labor organization. The amendment to Section 12 of the National Labor Relations Act imposes civil penalties on employers who commit unfair labor practices while employees are seeking representation by a labor organization. This includes back pay and liquidated damages for violations. The amendment to Section 12 of the National Labor Relations Act imposes civil penalties of up to $20,000 for each violation on employers who commit unfair labor practices before a collective bargaining contract is in place. The penalties take into account the seriousness of the violation and its impact on the charging party, others seeking to exercise their rights, or the public interest.
